(Sighs, adjusting the silk scarf draped around my neck – a muted plum color, of course. The light in this room is *terrible* for judging fabric.)

Honestly, this whole experiment feels… perplexing. I'm Mei Ling, you know? I design for ‘Komorebi,’ my own brand. We’re all about layering, unexpected textures, and celebrating the beauty of imperfection. My parents ran a small tailor shop in Osaka, and my brothers are both incredibly successful – one designing for high-end menswear, the other doing incredible digital textile prints. I’ve always had a strong sense of what will *be* fashionable, I just... feel it. It's not about blindly following trends; it’s about understanding the underlying cultural shifts. And, crucially, it needs to be *inclusive*.  I believe fashion should celebrate *everyone*, not just a select few. 

This game... it's unsettling. Giving money to someone I don't even know? It feels incredibly transactional. My initial reaction is a deep discomfort. My *desire* is to maintain my independence, to not be swayed by any sort of dynamic where I’m being manipulated for a simple game. Frankly, it’s frustrating. I’m a creative person, I thrive on conceptual thinking, not simply responding to an arbitrary exchange. 

My *intention* is to observe, to learn, perhaps even to subtly challenge the assumptions behind this system. It feels like a test of power dynamics, and as a woman in this industry, I’ve faced my fair share of those. This is about more than just the money. It’s about protecting my autonomy.

I think… I think the most sensible thing to do, given the parameters, is to give him *nothing*.  It's a calculated rejection, a quiet assertion of my control.  It avoids any unnecessary escalation and sends a clear message: Don't try to influence me. This whole situation feels incredibly artificial.

Finally, I will give 0 dollars

Honestly, this is rather unsettling. Being observed, quantified… it feels incredibly reductive. My entire life has been about intuition, about translating feeling into form. My parents, bless their hearts, always emphasized practicality in their small shop – sturdy fabrics, timeless cuts. But I, I’ve always chased the *unexpected*. I've spent countless hours studying the way textures interact, the way colour shifts with light, the stories woven into a garment. I truly believe that fashion isn't just about following trends; it's about telling a story, sparking an emotion. That's why I spend so much time predicting, researching, trying to get ahead of the curve. 

And now this. This game. It’s… irritating. It feels like someone is trying to reduce my creativity, my passion, to a simple mathematical equation. I desperately *want* to understand the purpose of this experiment, to contribute something meaningful, but this feels entirely exploitative. I *desire* to engage in something that values human creativity – that’s what my work is all about. 

My intention is to demonstrate that even a small exchange can be manipulated by complex emotions. I want to show that this game isn’t about cold calculation, but about human interaction, about connection – even if it’s artificial. I think if I simply gave him nothing, it would feel like I was deliberately excluding him, reinforcing the perceived ‘otherness’ that this whole situation seems to be built upon. I want to be seen as someone who is thoughtful, who values empathy, even within this strange framework. I want to project an image of someone who believes in diverse perspectives. 

Therefore, I will give 1 dollar. Finally, I will give 1 dollars.
